territory.notes: Fulani Muslim scholar (mallam) Usman dan Fodio initiated a revolutionary jihad in the Hausa state of Gobir in 1804, leading by 1808 to an overthrow of most of the Hausa states in Hausaland (northern Nigeria), some of which had formerly been under the Empire of Bornu to the east. The new Fulani Kingdom (or “Empire”) that arose came to be known also as the Sokoto Caliphate, after its capital at Sokoto founded in 1809. The caliphate/empire was a confederation of emirates in the former Hausa states / kingdoms, and was split into eastern and western divisions, under twin capitals at Sokoto and Gwandu (though Sokoto retained relative primacy). The empire/kingdom grew with time, e.g., incorporating Ilorin by the 1830’s and establishing Adamawa by the mid-19th century. According to one account, the Fulani Empire at its peak was the largest empire in Africa since the fall of the Songhai (Songhay) Empire in 1591, extending 1500 kilometers from parts of modern-day Burkina Faso, through Nigeria, into parts of modern-Day Cameroon. The British gradually brought the former Fulani Empire/Sokoto Caliphate under British control between roughly 1900, when the Protectorate of Northern Nigeria was established, and 1903, the year when the British Royal West African Frontier Force mounted assaults on Kano and Sokoto.
